                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Thesis Preparation</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EGYT 2990 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 14971]</span></h3>


  	For graduate students who have met the tuition requirement and are paying the registration fee to continue active enrollment while preparing a thesis.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


		

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>E: Grad Enrollment Fee/Dist Prep</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Reading and Research</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>ASYR 2980 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15074]</span></h3>


  	Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Matthew+T+Rutz">Matthew T Rutz</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Reading and Research</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>ASYR 2980 S02 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15075]</span></h3>


  	Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=John+M+Steele">John M Steele</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Babylon: Myth and Reality</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>ASYR 0300 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15156]</span></h3>


  	From the Hanging Gardens of Babylon to the Tower of Babel to Babylon 5, the city of Babylon in ancient Iraq holds an important place in contemporary culture. But how much of what is commonly known of Babylon is true? In this course we will explore the ancient city of Babylon through its texts and archaeological remains and investigate the ways Babylon has been viewed over the past two thousand years. Enrollment limited to 20 first year students. Instructor permission required. FYS WRIT
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>20</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd></dd>
			
		


																	
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=John+M+Steele">John M Steele</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
											
	<dt>Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Tyler+S+Roeder">Tyler S Roeder</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
									
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">10:30 - 11:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>13</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147ca3-5df4eee3-015d-f6cc01c9-00005a10events%40brown.edu/">Brown Bag Series in Archaeology: Katia Sch&ouml;rle (Joukowsky Institute for Archaeology, Brown University) - Economic Integration Principles and Competitive Markets in the Roman World: An Example from the Edge (Palmyra)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">

          Nov        </span>

        <section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/egyptology/sites/brown.edu.academics.egyptology/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Introduction to Akkadian</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>ASYR 1000 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15157]</span></h3>


  	An intensive introduction to the cuneiform writing system and the basic grammar and vocabulary of Akkadian, a language first attested over four thousand years ago in Mesopotamia (modern Iraq). The earliest known member of the Semitic family of languages (like Arabic and Hebrew), Akkadian was in use for over two thousand years across a wide expanse of the ancient Near East. Students will learn the classical Old Babylonian dialect of Akkadian (ca. 1800 BCE) and read Mesopotamian texts in the original, including selections from the Laws of Hammurabi, as well as excerpts from myths, hymns, prayers, historical documents, and letters.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>20</dd>
		
		


																	
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Matthew+T+Rutz">Matthew T Rutz</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
											
	<dt>Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Zachary+M+Rubin">Zachary M Rubin</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
									
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">11:00 - 11:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>16</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Akkadian Literary and Religious Texts</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>ASYR 2400 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15158]</span></h3>


  	Readings in Akkadian literary and religious texts in the original language and script. Possible genres include myths, proverbs, and literary miscellanea as well as prayers, hymns, incantations, rituals, prophecies, and divinatory texts. This course is intended primarily for graduate students and may be repeated for credit. A reading knowledge of Akkadian cuneiform is required.  A reading knowledge of both German and French is recommended but not required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>40</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Matthew+T+Rutz">Matthew T Rutz</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">14:30 - 17:00 Tue - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>03</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Babylonian Astronomy</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>ASYR 2710 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15164]</span></h3>


  	An advanced seminar on Babylonian astronomy, taking both a technical and a cultural perspective on the history of this ancient science.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>10</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=John+M+Steele">John M Steele</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->
        
                <div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column"> 
	
	<div id="block-menu-primary-links" class="clear-block block block-menu ">

  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Introduction to Classical Hieroglyphic Egyptian Writing and Language (Middle Egyptian I)</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EGYT 1310 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15165]</span></h3>


  	Much of this two-semester sequence is spent learning the signs, vocabulary, and grammar of one of the oldest languages known. By the end of this introductory year, students read authentic texts of biographical, historical, and literary significance. The cornerstone course in the Department of Egyptology-essential for any serious work in this field and particularly recommended for students in archaeology, history, classics, and religious studies. No prerequisites.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=James+P+Allen">James P Allen</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">09:00 - 10:20 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>08</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Selections from Middle Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EGYT 1330 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15166]</span></h3>


  	Readings from the various genres of classical Egyptian literature, including stories and other literary texts, historical inscriptions, and religious compositions.  Students will be expected to translate and discuss assigned texts.  Prerequisite: EGYT 1310, 1320.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


																	
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=James+P+Allen">James P Allen</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
											
	<dt>Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Maria+V+Almansa+Villatoro">Maria V Almansa Villatoro</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
									
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">08:30 - 09:50 Mon, Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>01</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>

        </ul>
      </div>
    </div>

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">History of Egypt I</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EGYT 1430 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15168]</span></h3>


  	A survey of the history and society of ancient Egypt from prehistoric times to the end of the Eighteenth Dynasty (ca. 5000-1300 BC). Readings include translations from the original documents that serve as primary sources for the reconstruction of ancient Egyptian history. WRIT
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>56</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd>Writing - Designated Courses</dd>
			
		


																	
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Laurel+D+Bestock">Laurel D Bestock</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
											
	<dt>Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Federico+Zangani">Federico Zangani</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
									
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">12:00 - 12:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>12</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          30        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147ca3-5e6ffa22-015e-72a601c8-000004f2events%40brown.edu/">Brown Bag Series in Archaeology: Brian Lander (History, Brown University) - Living with Wetlands in the Yangzi Valley</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Dec        </span>
        <span class="day">
          07        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147ca3-5e6ffa22-015e-72ac08dc-00001a9aevents%40brown.edu/">Brown Bag Series in Archaeology: Graham Oliver (Classics, Brown University) - Re-Thinking Things: Archaeological Theory, Words on Objects, and Mediation. Reflections from the Greek Inscriptions in the RISD Museum</a>
          </li>
          </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul><!-- close out the last date -->

        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Seminar in Biblical Studies: Ugaritic (RELS 2100F)</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>ASYR 2920 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 17137]</span></h3>


  	Interested students must register for RELS 2100F.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
		
		
		


		

	
				
		
		
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

	<div id="calendar" class="clear-block block block-calwidget ">
	
	<h2>CALENDAR</h2>	
		<div class="content"><section class="events-list">
      <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Oct        </span>
        <span class="day">
          19        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147ca3-5e0e215f-015e-0fa02e18-00005207events%40brown.edu/">Brown Bag Series in Archaeology: Eva Mol (Joukowsky Institute for Archaeology, Brown University) - Making Myth Real: Objects in Herodotus&rsquo; Histories and Material Epistemology</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Oct        </span>
        <span class="day">
          25        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147ca3-5f2438b8-015f-259d6e4f-00005888events%40brown.edu/">Fake New World</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">

          Oct        </span>

          26        </span></h5>

              <li class="event  even">

            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>

        <section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/egyptology/sites/brown.edu.academics.egyptology/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Readings in Ancient Egyptian</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EGYT 2300 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 17281]</span></h3>


  	Advanced readings in ancient Egyptian texts in the original script and language. Readings will be selected from a particular genre, historical period, or site. This course is intended primarily for graduate students and may be repeated for credit. A reading knowledge of ancient Egyptian is required. A reading knowledge of both German and French is strongly recommended but not required.
					<h6>Section specific notes:</h6>
			<div class="section-text">Instructor approval</div>
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=James+P+Allen">James P Allen</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->
        
                <div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column"> 
	
	<div id="block-menu-primary-links" class="clear-block block block-menu ">

        <section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/egyptology/sites/brown.edu.academics.egyptology/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">
    <div class="banner-text">
      <a href="/academics/egyptology/" title="" style="height:200px;" class="bare-banner-link"></a>    </div>
  </section>
      
  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Color and Culture in the Ancient Near East</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>ASYR 1160 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 17294]</span></h3>


  	This seminar investigates the meaning of color as a culturally mediated and culturally embedded phenomenon using case studies drawn from the civilizations of the ancient Near East and Aegean. Employing contemporary critical theories from cognition, phenomenology, linguistics and material culture studies, we will explore how human beings perceived, categorized and valued color in ways that vary cross-culturally.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>20</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Shiyanthi+Thavapalan">Shiyanthi Thavapalan</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">14:30 - 15:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>03</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

<header id="header-region">
<section id="audience-gateways">
  <div class="marginator">
    <h6>Information For:</h6>
    <ul>
      <li id="gateway-current-students" class="first"><a href="/gateway/current-students">Current Students</a></li>
      <li id="gateway-faculty"><a href="/gateway/faculty">Faculty</a></li>
      <li id="gateway-staff"><a href="/gateway/staff">Staff</a></li>
      <li id="gateway-families"><a href="/gateway/families">Families</a></li>
      <li id="gateway-alumni"><a href="/gateway/alumni">Alumni</a></li>
      <li id="gateway-friends-and-neighbors" class="last"><a href="/gateway/friends-and-neighbors">Friends &amp; Neighbors</a></li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</section>

        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Courses for Fall 2017</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                              <div id="tabs-wrapper" class="clear-block">
            <ul class="tabs primary">
              <li class="active" ><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/egya" class="active"> EGYA</a></li>

                                        <div class="clear-block"> <div class="content">



		<div class="course-section" id="EGYT">
				<h3>EGYT</h3>
			
				<ul class="course-list">
										<li id="EGYT1310">
					<h4>Introduction to Classical Hieroglyphic Egyptian Writing and Language (Middle Egyptian I)</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Much of this two-semester sequence is spent learning the signs, vocabulary, and grammar of one of the oldest languages known. By the end of this introductory year, students read authentic texts of biographical, historical, and literary significance. The cornerstone course in the Department of Egyptology-essential for any serious work in this field and particularly recommended for students in archaeology, history, classics, and religious studies. No prerequisites. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15165">EGYT 1310 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Allen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EGYT1330">
					<h4>Selections from Middle Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Readings from the various genres of classical Egyptian literature, including stories and other literary texts, historical inscriptions, and religious compositions.  Students will be expected to translate and discuss assigned texts.  Prerequisite: EGYT 1310, 1320. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15166">EGYT 1330 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Allen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EGYT1430">
					<h4>History of Egypt I</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">A survey of the history and society of ancient Egypt from prehistoric times to the end of the Eighteenth Dynasty (ca. 5000-1300 BC). Readings include translations from the original documents that serve as primary sources for the reconstruction of ancient Egyptian history. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15168">EGYT 1430 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Bestock</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EGYT1910">
					<h4>Senior Seminar</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=12823">EGYT 1910 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Allen</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
																				<div class="additional-sections">
															
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=12824">EGYT 1910 S02</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Depuydt</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=12825">EGYT 1910 S03</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Rutz</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=12826">EGYT 1910 S04</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Bestock</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=12827">EGYT 1910 S05</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Steele</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EGYT2300">
					<h4>Readings in Ancient Egyptian</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Advanced readings in ancient Egyptian texts in the original script and language. Readings will be selected from a particular genre, historical period, or site. This course is intended primarily for graduate students and may be repeated for credit. A reading knowledge of ancient Egyptian is required. A reading knowledge of both German and French is strongly recommended but not required. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=17281">EGYT 2300 S01</a></h5>
															<div class="section-text">Instructor approval</div>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Allen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EGYT2970">
					<h4>Preliminary Examination Preparation</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">For graduate students who have met the tuition requirement and are paying the registration fee to continue active enrollment while preparing for a preliminary examination. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=14970">EGYT 2970 S01</a></h5>

					<h4>Courses of Interest to Concentrators in Egyptology and Assyriology</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">The following courses may be of interest to Egyptology concentrators.  Please see the sponsoring department for the time and location of each course.<br><br>
<b>Archaeology and the Ancient World</b><br>
ARCH 1630 Fighting Pharaohs: Ancient Egyptian Warfare<br>
ARCH 2115 Ancient Mediterranean Scripts<br>
ARCH 2725 The Making of Egypt<br> </div>

	</div> <!-- end .course-section -->

	<div class="course-section" id="ASYR">
				<h3>ASYR</h3>
			
				<ul class="course-list">
										<li id="ASYR0300">
					<h4>Babylon: Myth and Reality</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">From the Hanging Gardens of Babylon to the Tower of Babel to Babylon 5, the city of Babylon in ancient Iraq holds an important place in contemporary culture. But how much of what is commonly known of Babylon is true? In this course we will explore the ancient city of Babylon through its texts and archaeological remains and investigate the ways Babylon has been viewed over the past two thousand years. Enrollment limited to 20 first year students. Instructor permission required. FYS WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15156">ASYR 0300 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Steele</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="ASYR1000">
					<h4>Introduction to Akkadian</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">An intensive introduction to the cuneiform writing system and the basic grammar and vocabulary of Akkadian, a language first attested over four thousand years ago in Mesopotamia (modern Iraq). The earliest known member of the Semitic family of languages (like Arabic and Hebrew), Akkadian was in use for over two thousand years across a wide expanse of the ancient Near East. Students will learn the classical Old Babylonian dialect of Akkadian (ca. 1800 BCE) and read Mesopotamian texts in the original, including selections from the Laws of Hammurabi, as well as excerpts from myths, hymns, prayers, historical documents, and letters. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15157">ASYR 1000 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Rutz</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="ASYR1160">
					<h4>Color and Culture in the Ancient Near East</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This seminar investigates the meaning of color as a culturally mediated and culturally embedded phenomenon using case studies drawn from the civilizations of the ancient Near East and Aegean. Employing contemporary critical theories from cognition, phenomenology, linguistics and material culture studies, we will explore how human beings perceived, categorized and valued color in ways that vary cross-culturally. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=17294">ASYR 1160 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Thavapalan</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="ASYR2400">
					<h4>Akkadian Literary and Religious Texts</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Readings in Akkadian literary and religious texts in the original language and script. Possible genres include myths, proverbs, and literary miscellanea as well as prayers, hymns, incantations, rituals, prophecies, and divinatory texts. This course is intended primarily for graduate students and may be repeated for credit. A reading knowledge of Akkadian cuneiform is required.  A reading knowledge of both German and French is recommended but not required. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15158">ASYR 2400 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Rutz</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="ASYR2710">
					<h4>Babylonian Astronomy</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">An advanced seminar on Babylonian astronomy, taking both a technical and a cultural perspective on the history of this ancient science. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15164">ASYR 2710 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Steele</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="ASYR2920">
					<h4>Seminar in Biblical Studies: Ugaritic (RELS 2100F)</h4>
					<div class="course-overview"> </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=17137">ASYR 2920 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="ASYR2980">
					<h4>Reading and Research</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15074">ASYR 2980 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Rutz</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
																				<div class="additional-sections">
															
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15075">ASYR 2980 S02</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Steele</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="ASYR2990">
					<h4>Thesis Preparation</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">For graduate students who have met the tuition requirement and are paying the registration fee to continue active enrollment while preparing a thesis. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=14948">ASYR 2990 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>E: Grad Enrollment Fee/Dist Prep</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>

<script type="text/javascript">
	// @todo: make show/hide link dynamically generated
	$(document).ready(function(){
	
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").hide();

		// add additional sections toggle link
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").each(function(i,el){
			var numSections = $(".section", $(this)).length;
			numSections = (numSections == 1) ? numSections + " additional section" : numSections + " additional sections";
			var anchor = $(this).parents("li").attr('id');
			$(this).after('<span class="section-count">[<a href="#' + anchor + '">Show ' + numSections + '</a>]</span>');
		});

		// now add the show/hide event listeners		
		$(".section-count").each(function(i,el){
			$("a", this).bind("click keypress", function(){
				$(".additional-sections", $(this).parents("li")).slideToggle("fast");
				window.location.hash = $(this).attr("href");
				if($(this).html().match(/Show/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
				} else if($(this).html().match(/Hide/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Hide", "Show"));
				}
				this.text(($('#toggle').text() == 'Show more') ? 'Show less' : 'Show more');
				return false;
			});
		});
		
		if (window.location.hash) {
			var hash = window.location.hash;
			if(hash.match(/#[0-9]{4}/)) {
				$(hash +  " .additional-sections").slideDown("fast");
				$(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html($(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
			}
		}

	});
</script>
 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Courses for Fall 2017</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                              <div id="tabs-wrapper" class="clear-block">
            <ul class="tabs primary">
              <li ><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/egya"> EGYA</a></li>
<li ><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/asyr">ASYR</a></li>
<li class="active" ><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/egyt" class="active">EGYT</a></li>

            </ul>
          </div>
                                        <div class="clear-block"> <div class="content">



		<div class="course-section" id="egyt">
			
				<ul class="course-list">
										<li id="EGYT1310">
					<h4>Introduction to Classical Hieroglyphic Egyptian Writing and Language (Middle Egyptian I)</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Much of this two-semester sequence is spent learning the signs, vocabulary, and grammar of one of the oldest languages known. By the end of this introductory year, students read authentic texts of biographical, historical, and literary significance. The cornerstone course in the Department of Egyptology-essential for any serious work in this field and particularly recommended for students in archaeology, history, classics, and religious studies. No prerequisites. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15165">EGYT 1310 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Allen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EGYT1330">
					<h4>Selections from Middle Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Readings from the various genres of classical Egyptian literature, including stories and other literary texts, historical inscriptions, and religious compositions.  Students will be expected to translate and discuss assigned texts.  Prerequisite: EGYT 1310, 1320. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15166">EGYT 1330 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Allen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EGYT1430">
					<h4>History of Egypt I</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">A survey of the history and society of ancient Egypt from prehistoric times to the end of the Eighteenth Dynasty (ca. 5000-1300 BC). Readings include translations from the original documents that serve as primary sources for the reconstruction of ancient Egyptian history. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15168">EGYT 1430 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Bestock</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EGYT1910">
					<h4>Senior Seminar</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=12823">EGYT 1910 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Allen</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
																				<div class="additional-sections">
															
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=12824">EGYT 1910 S02</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Depuydt</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=12825">EGYT 1910 S03</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Rutz</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=12826">EGYT 1910 S04</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Bestock</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=12827">EGYT 1910 S05</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Steele</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EGYT2300">
					<h4>Readings in Ancient Egyptian</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Advanced readings in ancient Egyptian texts in the original script and language. Readings will be selected from a particular genre, historical period, or site. This course is intended primarily for graduate students and may be repeated for credit. A reading knowledge of ancient Egyptian is required. A reading knowledge of both German and French is strongly recommended but not required. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=17281">EGYT 2300 S01</a></h5>
															<div class="section-text">Instructor approval</div>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Allen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EGYT2970">
					<h4>Preliminary Examination Preparation</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">For graduate students who have met the tuition requirement and are paying the registration fee to continue active enrollment while preparing for a preliminary examination. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=14970">EGYT 2970 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>E: Grad Enrollment Fee/Dist Prep</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EGYT2980">
					<h4>Reading and Research</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">

										<li id="EGYT2990">
					<h4>Thesis Preparation</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">For graduate students who have met the tuition requirement and are paying the registration fee to continue active enrollment while preparing a thesis. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/egyptology/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=14971">EGYT 2990 S01</a></h5>

				</li>
										<li id="EGYTXLIST">
					<h4>Courses of Interest to Concentrators in Egyptology and Assyriology</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">The following courses may be of interest to Egyptology concentrators.  Please see the sponsoring department for the time and location of each course.<br><br>
<b>Archaeology and the Ancient World</b><br>
ARCH 1630 Fighting Pharaohs: Ancient Egyptian Warfare<br>
ARCH 2115 Ancient Mediterranean Scripts<br>
ARCH 2725 The Making of Egypt<br> </div>
		
					<div class="sections">

	</div> <!-- end .course-section -->



</div>



<script type="text/javascript">
	// @todo: make show/hide link dynamically generated
	$(document).ready(function(){
	
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").hide();

		// add additional sections toggle link
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").each(function(i,el){
			var numSections = $(".section", $(this)).length;
			numSections = (numSections == 1) ? numSections + " additional section" : numSections + " additional sections";
			var anchor = $(this).parents("li").attr('id');
			$(this).after('<span class="section-count">[<a href="#' + anchor + '">Show ' + numSections + '</a>]</span>');
		});

		// now add the show/hide event listeners		
		$(".section-count").each(function(i,el){
			$("a", this).bind("click keypress", function(){
				$(".additional-sections", $(this).parents("li")).slideToggle("fast");
				window.location.hash = $(this).attr("href");
				if($(this).html().match(/Show/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
				} else if($(this).html().match(/Hide/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Hide", "Show"));
				}
				this.text(($('#toggle').text() == 'Show more') ? 'Show less' : 'Show more');
				return false;
			});
		});
		
		if (window.location.hash) {
			var hash = window.location.hash;
			if(hash.match(/#[0-9]{4}/)) {
				$(hash +  " .additional-sections").slideDown("fast");
				$(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html($(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
			}
		}

	});
</script>
 </div>
                     </div>

  <div id="content">

                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-13" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>PhD Program in Egyptology and Assyriology</h2>
<p><span style="color:#000000">Brown is one of the premier institutions for the study of Egyptology, Assyriology, and the history of ancient science, and our PhD students train in the foundational areas of our disciplines: the languages, literatures, history, and material culture of Egypt and Mesopotamia in their wider environment. The department offers instruction in the core ancient languages that are essential for research in our fields: Akkadian (Babylonian and Assyrian, all stages), Egyptian (all stages), Hittite, and Sumerian. Instruction in Arabic, Aramaic, Greek, Hebrew, Latin, Sanskrit, Syriac, and Ugaritic is also available at Brown. In addition to training in philology and critical research methods, our students also become conversant in the archaeological sequence, art and architecture, and repertoires of material culture found across the ancient Near East.</span></p>
<p>Brown’s doctoral program in Egyptology and Assyriology has a number of distinguishing features:</p>
<ul>
<li>We offer in-depth disciplinary training that allows our students to pursue focused research in any one of our core fields: Assyriology, Egyptology, the history of ancient science, and the archaeology of Egypt and the Near East.</li>
<li>We encourage creative interdisciplinary work, including but not limited to research that bridges Egyptology, Assyriology, and the history of ancient science in innovative ways. Our doctoral students have the opportunity to do coursework in and cultivate stimulating intellectual relationships with faculty from Anthropology, Classics, History, the Joukowsky Institute for Archaeology and the Ancient World, and Religious Studies. In addition Brown’s Graduate School has an Open Graduate Program that allows interested doctoral students at Brown to pursue a concurrent master’s degree in a secondary field that is outside the scope of their doctoral program.</li>
<li>We provide significant funding both in the department and across the university to support graduate students' original research. Our doctoral students have recently used support from the department and university to carry out research in museum collections in the US, Europe, and Africa; to participate in archaeological fieldwork (survey and excavation) in Egypt, Sudan, and Turkey; and to present the results of their research at international conferences and symposia.</li>
<li>We emphasize developing our students professionally and encourage students to reach important early career milestones during their time in the program, such as giving conference papers and submitting academic publications; to that end we have incorporated valuable professional academic skills into our curriculum and assessment.</li>
<li>We provide a variety of opportunities for our PhD students to train as teachers and develop valuable teaching skills that will be useful in a wide variety of educational settings, including research universities, museums, or teaching colleges focused on the liberal arts.</li>
</ul>
<p>A few areas of particular interest to the department’s faculty include: ancient science (astronomy and astrology, timekeeping and calendrics, divination and medicine); cultural interactions throughout the Mediterranean, Near East, and Africa in the second and first millennia BC; religion and ritual in the ancient Near East, from Egypt and Sudan to Anatolia and Mesopotamia; the history of the Egyptian language and its grammar; the origins and development of writing and the diffusion and reception of cuneiform, hieroglyphic, and alphabetic scripts in the ancient world; kingship and monumentality in ancient Egypt and Sudan; the integration of textual and archaeological methodologies; Coptic manuscripts; the ancient Near East in classical periods and Greek and Roman cultures’ perceptions of the more ancient past; Mesopotamian and Egyptian literature; ancient empires of the Near East in context; and the origins of Egyptian civilization.</p>
<h2><strong>PhD Tracks</strong></h2>
<p>The department currently offers three tracks: (1) Assyriology (2) Egyptology, and (3) History of the Exact Sciences in Antiquity. Each track has different course requirements, details of which may be found in the Graduate Student Handbook. Students who enter the program in one track may switch to another track providing they are still able to complete the coursework requirements by the end of their third year.<br /><strong></strong></p>
<p><strong>Applying for Graduate Studies</strong><br />We welcome applications to our PhD program from prospective students interested in pursuing graduate studies in Egyptology, Assyriology, and the History of the Exact Sciences in Antiquity. All applications must be submitted online to Brown's Graduate School.<br /><br />For students accepted into the program, Brown’s Graduate School typically guarantees five years of full funding (tuition, fees, health insurance, and stipend to cover living expenses). The typical PhD program at Brown therefore includes three years of coursework and exams, followed by two years dedicated to researching and writing a doctoral dissertation that constitutes an original contribution to scholarship in the student’s field.<br /><br />Egyptology and Assyriology has overlapping interests with a number of other academic units at Brown, especially Anthropology, Ancient History, Classics, Religious Studies, and the Joukowsky Institute for Archaeology and the Ancient World. We advise prospective students with interests that cross multiple disciplines to contact the faculty in the relevant programs to discuss which program would be the best fit. The Department of Egyptology and Assyriology will normally not consider applications from prospective students who have applied to more than one program at Brown.<br /><br />Further details about applying for our graduate program may be found <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/programs/egyptology-and-assyriology.">here</a>. Please note that the deadline for submitting applications to the Graduate School is 15 December for admission into the program for the following September.</p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

	</div>

</article>

            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147ca3-5e0e215f-015e-0f4d176e-000004cdevents%40brown.edu/">Egyptology Graduate Conference</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">

          16        </span></h5>

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate Research Award</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-207" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h3>Egyptology and Assyriology Graduate Research Award in Academic Year 2017-18<span>&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></h3>
<h2><strong><span class="large">&nbsp;</span></strong></h2>
<h2>Description and Scope</h2>
<p><strong>&nbsp;</strong>The Graduate Research Award in Egyptology and Assyriology exists to support outstanding research by doctoral students in the department’s three tracks: Assyriology, Egyptology, and History of the Exact Sciences in Antiquity. The funds, when available, will be set aside on an annual basis at the discretion of the department Chair. Awards must be pre-approved by the Director of Graduate Studies (DGS) prior to incurring. The maximum amount that can be requested per award cycle may vary from year to year. There is no minimum award. For various reasons students may not always be awarded the full amount requested.<br /><br />The annual maximum amount that can be requested for AY 2017-18 is <strong>$1,800</strong>.<br /><br />Academic activities that may be funded by the award include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Travel or research expenses associated with an approved dissertation project</li>
<li>Travel to present work at an academic conference, symposium, or workshop; students are expected to first exhaust funding sources available elsewhere at Brown</li>
<li>Travel for archaeological fieldwork or museum research; normally students will be funded for one such trip for experience, professional development, etc., but for subsequent trips their work should be directly related to a dissertation project and/or planned publication</li>
<li>Fees for publishing academic work (photography, etc.)</li>
</ul>
<p>Activities not supported include but are not limited to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Attending a conference, symposium, or workshop at which the student is not presenting academic work</li>
<li>Membership dues (unless required for presenting work at an academic conference)</li>
<li>Books, equipment</li>
<li>Alcoholic beverages or personal items</li>
<li>Any activity that is not pre-approved</li>
</ul>
<p>Students may not apply for an award retroactively.</p>
<h4>Application Process</h4>
<p><em>Eligibility</em><br />Only doctoral students in one of the department’s three tracks are eligible for this award. Students must be in years 1–5 in good academic standing and must have “Good” status with respect to academic progress. In extraordinary circumstances students may apply for funds in year 6, but such funds are not guaranteed. Students are not eligible to apply for more than one award per cycle (see below) but may apply for multiple awards in a given academic year.<br /><br /><em>Procedure</em><br />Applications must be submitted to the DGS, with a copy to the department manager, via email and include all of the following information:</p>
<ol>
<li>Student Name</li>
<li>Amount Requested</li>
<li>Description of the Proposed Activity: event name/dates/location/student role, including name of presentation if applicable</li>
<li>Detailed Budget and Rationale. NB: hotel rooms should be shared unless prior exception is allowed.</li>
<li>Filing for reimbursement: Submit Excel spreadsheet listing costs by category: registration/travel/hotel/food/misc. Include title of presentation and scan of itemized (not summary signature) receipts.</li>
</ol>
<p>The concise description (one page or less) of the proposed academic activity must include the date(s), location(s), and academic purpose and goals of the activity. The detailed, research-based budget should provide the rationale for the proposed expenditures and reflect that the student has looked into ways to minimize costs.<br /><br />Any publications or public presentations that result from funded research must expressly acknowledge departmental support.<br /><br />Awards are made by the DGS in consultation with the faculty, when necessary. Late or incomplete applications will not be accepted. Priority will be given to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Students applying for matching funds (e.g., Brown’s Doctoral Research Travel Grant)</li>
<li>Students applying to fund approved dissertation research</li>
<li>First-time applicants</li>
</ul>
<p>An award can be received in one of three cycles:</p>
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td>Award Start Date</td>
<td>Award End Date</td>
<td>Application Deadline</td>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Cycle 1</td>
<td>July 1</td>
<td>November 30</td>
<td>June 1</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Cycle 2</td>
<td>December 1</td>
<td>February 28/29</td>
<td>November 1</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Cycle 3</td>
<td>March 1</td>
<td>June 30</td>
<td>February 1</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Funds not allocated in one cycle are generally incorporated into the pool of available funds in subsequent cycles for the remainder of the fiscal year; likewise, allocated funds that are not spent may be carried over past the award end date until the end of the fiscal year. However, funds cannot be carried over into the new fiscal year. If a proposed project does not fit neatly into one cycle, every effort will be made to be flexible; in such cases students should plan ahead and consult with their advisor and the DGS about how to proceed. Awards are normally processed as reimbursements. Students are required to submit hard copies of original receipts to the Department Manager within two weeks of completing the funded activity.<br /><br /></p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->
